    Computational Mechanics of Soft Materials Lab (CMSML)

    The Group

    Computational Mechanics of Soft Materials Lab (CMSML)

    The Group

    Our group investigates the fundamental mechanics of soft and architected materials, emphasizing the interplay among mechanical deformation, transport phenomena, and electrical polarization. Through theoretical modeling, multiscale computational simulation, and targeted experiments, we aim to understand and computationally design multifunctional polymeric and biomimetic materials—including stretchable polymers that generate electricity, architected structures inspired by biological interfaces, synthetic tissue-like systems, and membrane materials with selective transport properties. Our interdisciplinary work advances fundamental knowledge in soft matter mechanics and guides the design of materials for energy harvesting, filtration, and beyond.

    • EMI 2025: Talk on size effects in soft materials

       By Berkin Dortdivanlioglu

      Posted on June 1, 2025

      Gave a talk on “Size-Dependent Instabilities in Highly Deformable Strain-Gradient Materials” at EMI 2025 in Anaheim, CA. Credit goes to the PhD student Jun for his work on this topic.

    • Berkin is elected as the new editor of the newsletter for the ASME technical committee of Mechanics of Soft Materials

       By bd24583

      Posted on February 25, 2025

      Berkin has been elected as the new editor of the ASME (Applied Mechanics Division) Technical Committee on Mechanics of Soft Materials. According to the policy, he will continue to serve the committee as secretary, then as vice chair, and finally as chair over the next four years.

    • We recieved the NSF CAREER Award!

       By bd24583

      Posted on February 13, 2025

      National Science Foundation (NSF) CAREER Award on CAREER: Multiscale Mechanics of Highly Deformable Strain-Gradient Electric Generators

    • Ashkan Received the Kolodzey Travel Award

       By jw55692

      Posted on October 31, 2024

      Ashkan received the Kolodzey Travel Award from the CAEE department at UT Austin, which allowed him to attend the MPM Workshop in Berkeley, CA, where he presented his research on Mechanics of Polymeric Porous Membranes using a Stabilized Extended B-Spline Material Point Method.

    • Ashkan Ali Madadi Presents at the 15th Annual MPM Workshop

       By jw55692

      Posted on September 9, 2024

      Ashkan attended the 15th Annual MPM Workshop at the University of California, Berkeley, held from September 5-6, 2024. He gave a presentation titled Mechanics of Porous Polymeric Membranes Using Stabilized Extended B-spline Material Point Method. Well done, Ashkan! [Read More]
